body.p:
I should gladly have written to you before this, but, though it
may sound very strange to you, I had not time. For the last 6 or 7 weeks,
whenever I had a moment from my duties, I had to sit at the sickbed of
my children. Now, thank God, they are improved and out of danger.
Naturally, I was hindered by this in doing anything for you. But I
hope to catch up. I have put in a notice in both the newspapers of this
city and handed over several copies of the “Occident” to the respective
editors of these newspapers so that they might be in the position to give
the public their judgment on it. Along with this letter, or perhaps sev-
eral days later, you will receive both newspapers. Whether this will
do some good or not, time will tell. I hope that it will not have been
in vain. Mr. Hart told me that he owes you for only 8 years of the Oc-
cident, and herewith sends $24.75. For the other books, he paid your
former agent, Louis Allen, since thelatter charged it to him in a bill.
Please write to me in your next letter whether this is correct. I have
not yet had time to collect from the others. Tendler wants to pay you for
only one year, namely the last one, but not for the two years mentioned
in your letter. Perhaps Mr. Tendler, who is at themoment in Philadelphia,
and who is about to take a journey to California, will visit you. He
wants you to send him the “Occident” as well as the “Advocate,” if the lat-
ter should see the light of day, on his own name to San Francisco each
month. I shall write to you again in the course of the coming month, if
possible also the subscription list and perhaps also send you money. Per-
haps you have paid attention to the notice in the “Asmonean” about Henry.
I would have written about it but thought that I ought to wait first for
the promised exposition of the matter, and then to reveal the true state
of affairs through the letters in his own hand as proof. But this much
I want to place at your disposal, that everything which the article in
the “Occident” contains is true, irrefutably true, except his removal.

He had every intention to move here; his books were here already, his
friends.tried to rent a house for him, a petition laid before the ?
congreggtion written and signed in his own hand, in which he asked the
synagogue room for a school. The majority, however, voted for Bernal.
I have letters in my possession which, when published, will certainly
not be in his favor, and will show his petty and unworthy intentions.
I wish you had other correspondents here. These might have written to
you occasionally about me, something that would be to my advantage. I
believe that at the present moment I have more friends here than upon my
arrival, and that my position in general is on a stronger footing than
in previous years. Last week I had a wedding, 2 sisters, on which oc-
casion the synagogue was filled with Jews and non Jews. And my speech
(text-Would that your heart were thus within you all the daysso that
all will go well with you forever) received general applause. I can
flatter myself that the same thing was the case with a speech on the
20th of Shebat, at thegrave of a dead member of this community, By the
name of Isaac Stern.

Have the goodness again to write to me about your own prospects in
your next letter, whether the clouds which darken your immediate future
are not beginning to become lighter, and especially whether your congre-
gation has not yet arrived at the conviction to which it must come, that
it will cease to occupy the first rung among Jewish congregations as soon
as you cease to be its minister.

Now one more thing—in the synagogue, there are still lying about
books and other effects which I bought for the congregational school be-
fore my departure from Philadelphia. Bernal wrote about this to Mr.Bitel
and Hart, but the congregation did not deliver the books to Bernal. I
am now commissioned to do the best possible with it for the congregation.
Don't you think that upon your request, Mr. Bitel will give us writing
paper in exchange for the unused books and effects? And for his share,

Mr. Hart several of your prayer books? These two articles would be as
welcome as money to myself and the congregation. Have the goodness to do
something in this matter, and to let me know about it.

My wife, who 5 weeks ago, presented me with a little girl, greets you
most respectfully. In a few weeks you will here more from
